text.text:
Your people are in town and you said you'd show them the ropes, but you've quite forgotten how to entertain. Friends, family, loved ones by the car load, your mate's mate who needs a place to stay, whoever they are they're looking to you for advice, fun and maybe even cool factor.

The bars below will help you do just that, show them something different, memorable, impressive. From plush hotel bars and sultry speakeasies to rough-and-ready happy hours under the arches - we've got you covered, buddy.
Go for... Three bars in one

tip.text:
Tom Aske and Tristan Stephenson (the cool kids behind London’s Worship Street Whistling Shop) decided Londoners need an education in whisky. Opening a bar with 250 different bottles is their answer. Of the short (whisky only) cocktail list we recommend the 40 Shades - made with Black Bush, Granny Smith and fennel pollen.

Instead of a stuffy bar full of tweed-wearing Old Boys, Black Rock is slick and minimalistic with a hip hop, electro-funk soundtrack. An 18ft, 185-year-old tree trunk in the middle of the room replaces the bar and bartenders will roam freely serving drinks. 2 different types of whisky are being aged within this trunk right now and can be poured from one end through a tap. Wondrous.

text.text:
Within the confines of the Napoleon Hotel you'll find a bumper pack of three bars, each a'top the other. On the first floor is The Devil's Darling (an opulent Russian-style drinking den); on the ground floor Sack (a Spanish-inspired sherry bar); and in the basement you'll find Black Rock (whisky bar extraordinaire - complete with an 18ft, 185-year-old tree trunk in the middle of the room in which whisky is slowly aged but also on tap). Wondrous.

All three do cocktails beautifully, so take your out-of-towner along to one, then surprise them with the other two. Boom, boom. boom.
Go for... Prized Whisky in swanky surrounds

tip.text:
Picture Olivander's for rich wizards with a particular proclivity for fine, rare whiskey and you've pretty much hit the malt on the head. This fine establishment just off Fleet Street looks like it's straight off of Pinterest - with its Art Deco aesthetic, its hanging plants, its wall of whiskeys and its plush, emerald green velour seating.

And yet Merchant House still manages to feel a lot like your local. Perch at the coppery bar with half a dozen oysters and a rye sazzy while you listen to your master mixologist recount the stories behind this or that poison. Gawk at the Peter Rabbit-style signature cocktail menu boasting a ton of fresh, floral and slightly soapy concoctions - or just do what we did, and go for whatever the super knowledgeable whiskey-head next to you ordered. It was delicious, but we might have had a few too many and forgotten what it was called...

text.text:
Your uncle's come down from Scotland and his expectations of London's whisky offerings are low. Little does he know you've got Merchant House in your back pocket.

Picture Olivander's wand shop but for rich wizards with a particular proclivity for fine, rare whisky and you've pretty much hit the malt on the head. Perch your uncle at the coppery bar with half a dozen oysters and a rye sazzy while you listen to your master mixologist recount the stories behind this or that poison. Stick that in your pipe, Uncle Joe.

tip.text:
Take one step into Nine Lives and you’re a million miles away from the hustle of London Bridge. From dark wood features and palm fronds to a vintage sound system and layers of incense, every detail has been carefully planned to create that elusive feeling of escapism. But that's not all this cocktail bar is up to. It's also making lots of noise on the sustainability train, with low waste cocktails, low plastic usage, up-cycled furniture and a herb garden out back (run by St Mungo's homeless charity no less).

And the results for your drinking pleasure? Sweet treats like the Kelross Daiquiri which replaces limes with relatively local Bramley apples; and the Kafé Kerna,l a non-alcoholic, bitter coffee number. If you've a more classical flavour palate, order the (off menu) Lutra which fills your mouth beautifully with Tanqueray, sake, dry white wine, lemon, sugar and creme de peche. At £9.50 you'd be hard pressed to find better in these ends.

text.text:
Take one step into Nine Lives and you’re a million miles away from the hustle of London Bridge. From dark wood features and palm fronds to a vintage sound system and layers of incense, every detail is reaching for that elusive feeling of escapism. 

But that's not all this cocktail bar is up to. It's also making lots of noise on the sustainability train, with low-waste cocktails, reduced plastic usage, up-cycled furniture and a herb garden out back (run by St Mungo's homeless charity no less).
Go for... Award winning cocktails & river views

tip.text:
Opened up in Mondrian Hotel in Southwark. The bar is incredibly swish dripping in plush pink seating, dark green marble and gold finishing - all very Art Deco, French boudoir vibes. If the company card is out, Dandelyan makes a particularly baller afterwork spot, or an impressive date option. The mixologist Ryan Cheti is the guy behind SuperLyan in Hoxton so you can be sure the cocktails will be inventive (he's not afraid to put pineapple Madeira and banana bitters in his Old Fashioned), delicious and low waste (they're big into the 'closed loop cocktail' trying to reduce waste in the industry - nice one Ryan).

Work your way through the botanical cocktail menu or treat your aunty to a 'wyld tea' with kitsch 1970’s cakes and savouries.

text.text:
Set in Mondrian Hotel in Southwark, this bar is incredibly swish dripping in plush pink seating, dark green marble and gold finishing - all very art deco, French boudoir vibes. If you really want to razzle dazzle em, this could be the one.

Work your way through the botanical cocktail menu or treat your aunty to a 'wyld tea' with kitsch 1970s cakes and savouries. It's won awards for World's Best Bar, it's got a delectable cocktail menu, and it's right on the river front. Wowza.
Go for... Hip hop and taxidermy

tip.text:
Well here's something... a cocktail bar that doesn't play chart music, or old school swing. Satan's Whiskers keeps things old school hip hop, which is why we keep our asses firmly in their seats again and again. It's a weird mix of semi-dive bar, with taxidermy exhibits littered around the place, but somehow doesn't feel 'omg I'm so quirky.'

The cocktails and food are seriously top notch. Instead of dry nibbles, we've actually had scallops here before, and sticky ribs. The drinks are always changing, but the potent Satan's Manhattan is a regular, and one we keep going back for.

text.text:
Well here's something... a cocktail bar that doesn't play chart music or old school swing. Satan's Whiskers keeps to old-school hip hop, which is why we find our asses in their seats again and again. It's a weird blend as a dive bar with taxidermy exhibits littered around the place, but somehow without feeling all, 'omg I'm so quirky.'

The cocktails and food are seriously top-notch too. Instead of dry nibbles, we've actually had scallops here before, and sticky ribs. Don't get that in the West Country do ya?

tip.text:
Stepping into Spiritland is like entering a time warp to bougie 70s New York, where affairs could be conducted in places with a bit of class about them. An audiophile bar, cafe and restaurant, this is a place where every last detail has been meticulously thought through to leave a treat for the senses - where you could happily spend hours surrounded by the soft, glowing orbs of light, submerging yourself in potent cocktails and getting into something serious.

The specially designed sound system is definitely centre stage and is put in the hands of excellent selectors every night of the week to drop grooving, crystal-clear jams: Auto Shazam is a must. It's a romantic, heady spot that has 'wooing' written all over it - although you might end up covering your date's mouth so you can hear the music.

text.text:
Spiritland is like entering a time warp to bougie 70s New York, where affairs could be conducted in places with a bit of class about them. An audiophile cocktail bar, cafe and restaurant, this place is a real treat for the senses. The specially designed sound system is definitely centre-stage and is put in the hands of excellent selectors every night of the week to drop grooving, crystal-clear jams.

You can meet your loved ones straight off the train at King's Cross and whisk them off to this upmarket listening paradise.
Go for... Happy hour and people watching

tip.text:
One of the leaders of Peckham's cool scene, Peckham Springs is always filled to the brim with creative types. And for good reason too. It's pretty hard to resist the cocktails - and their prices. Early evening happy hour, is one of the happiest we've had.

Springs also comes with a large outdoor space ideal for sparking up a rollie, modelling your thrift store jacket and gobbling whatever street food residency is the flavour of the day. Run by art students, it's about as chill as a cocktail bar can get and even has a gallery space attached.

text.text:
One of the leaders of Peckham's cool scene, Peckham Springs is always filled to the brim with creative types. And for good reason too. It's pretty hard to resist the cocktails - and their prices. And the early evening happy hour, is one of the happiest we've had. 

If you want your guest to think you’re in with the arty types then this is the place. They’ll be starry eyed in no time, and go home telling all sorts of tall tales about how edgy London is.
